qas.question: What was a disadvantage of DC system?
How can different range of voltages be supplied for AC locomotives?
What taps can provide lighting supply?
What will AC/DC motor be replaced with?
What is the main advantage of an induction motor?

answers.text: can run equally well on DC or AC of any frequency

plausible_answers.text: the power-wasting resistors used in DC locomotives for speed control were not needed in an AC locomotive

qas.question: What was an early disadvantage of AC?
One taps on the transformer can supply what?

plausible_answers.text: the classic "universal" AC/DC motor to be largely replaced

qas.question: The development of low power semiconductors caused what?
No modern electric locomotives are designed to handle what?
Combined low-voltage transformer windings supply what?

context: An early advantage of AC is that <b5_0>the <a0_0>power-wasting resistors<a0_0/> used in DC locomotives for speed control were not needed in an AC locomotive<b5_0/>: <a1_0>multiple taps on the transformer<a1_0/> can supply <b6_0>a range of voltages<b6_0/>. Separate <a2_0>low-voltage transformer windings<a2_0/> supply <b9_0>lighting<b9_0/> and the motors driving auxiliary machinery. More recently, the development of very high power semiconductors has caused <b7_0>the classic "universal" AC/DC motor to be largely replaced<b7_0/> with the <a3_0>three-phase induction motor<a3_0/> fed by a variable frequency drive, a special inverter that varies both frequency and voltage to control motor speed. These drives <a4_0>can run equally well on DC or AC of any frequency<a4_0/>, and many modern electric locomotives are designed to handle <b8_0>different supply voltages and frequencies<b8_0/> to simplify cross-border operation.
